review_blob: 18cl bottle with thanks to Doodler, much appreciated Scott!  Pours almost flat with a thin, spotty and slow rising tan head.  Aroma is nice with a rich cognac aroma amongst some espresso and light chocolate.  Flavor follows suit, with more cognac flavor and lesser notes of sweet milk chocolate and espresso.  A better compliment to the base beer on this one than the Wild Turkey.

25cl bottle, with thanks to heyta, much appreciated Mark!  Pours dark black with a large and lasting mocha colored head.  Aroma is molasses, caramel, roasted malts, espresso, milk chocolate, vanilla and light bourbon.  Flavor is a touch sweet, with more roasted malts, chocolate, oak, espresso, and bourbon.  The bourbon barrel aspects arent overbearing but the sweetness is a bit distracting and keeps this from being better balanced.

750ml bottle with a big thanks to GodOfThunder, thanks dude!  Pours an inky pitch black with a minimal dark brown head.  Aroma is big on the barrel, with heavy roast, some espresso and char.  Flavor follows the nose with more barrel, sticky, sweet and roast.  This one was interesting but just a little too far over the edge.
beer_name: Cigar City Marshal Zhukovs Imperial Stout - Double Barrel-aged 2010

review_blob: 18cl bottle, #1553, bottled in Feb 2011, with another thanks to Doodler!  Pours dark brown/black with only the most minimal loose collection of larger bubbles.  Aroma of caramel, milk chocolate, vanilla, and similar dessert qualities mingled amongst the barrel notes.  Flavor also balances the beer and barrel blend as best as it can, but of course brings a little heat and bourbon along with the chocolate, vanilla and caramel.  Wouldnt want much more in one sitting than this bottle size, but a nice cool evening dessert beer.
beer_name: De Molen Hel & Verdoemenis Wild Turkey BA

review_blob: Trying to go by memory on this one.  Good memories and tasty, and wouldnt do a good job describing it anyway.  Pours a nifty pinkish golden hue with a nice white head.  Aroma has some watermelon, tart raspberries, and a little funk.  Flavor brings on the tart and sour, juicy fruits, and nicely balanced overall.
beer_name: Russian River Framboise for a Cure (2010)

review_blob: 750ml 2008 bottle from Doodler, muchas gracias my friend!  After trying Squatters 529 thanks to Beastiefan2k I was really jazzed to get to try this one, and it did not disappoint.  Pours a bright golden yellow with a great brighter white head.  Aroma was a nice blend of citrus and rind, some floral, funk, tart lemon and other fruits; a great nose overall.  Flavor was also engaging and enjoyable and would have been fine to sip on this one all night.  Great stuff and easily exceeded my expectations.  I just need to find a way to score another few bottles now!

750ml bottle in trade from heyta, thanks Mark!  Shared this along with Lente, so a nice compare/contrast as they were more different than expected.  Pours a slightly darker hazy golden with a good sized white head.  Aroma is citrus, grass, barnyard, some fruit rind, light brettiness, and similar notes that work well together.  Flavor is a notch above Lente, tasty and lasting, with more light barnyard and brett, grass, citrus, and other notes.  This was well nuanced and nicely done.

750ml bottle in trade from heyta, thanks Mark!  Shared this along with Zomer, so a nice compare/contrast as they were more different than expected.  Pours hazy golden with a good sized white head.  Aroma is citrus, grass, some fruit rind, and positive but poorly described notes of heated plastic/rubber that still work well.  Flavor is very drinkable and tasty, with more grass, citrus, and other notes.  The Zomer was better by a hair for me, but both were fun to try next to the other.

22oz. bomber.  Okay, after a long hiatus I guess I better start rating again.  Although my skills in deScription have not improved one iota since my first rating almost 5 years ago, I am still enjoying the ride, so guess thats all that matters anyway.  Pours the typical Impy Stout dark brown-black with a minimal darker tan head.  Aroma is heavily roasted malts, milk and bittersweet chocolate, some mild roasty coffee, and sweet molasses.  Flavor is loads of sweet and alcohol, with more bittersweet and milk chocolate, heavy roast, and a little coffee.  Even with the awesome cooler fall weather I just couldnt get into this one, and wondering if my Impy Stout days are moving behind me.  How am I possibly going to stay on the Most Top 50 list if thats the case?!?!
beer_name: Goose Island Big John Imperial Stout

review_blob: 750ml bottle.  Pours a mostly clear copper-amber with a large frothy off-white head.  Aroma is cocoa nibs, delicate bittersweet chocolate, and some dusty cocoa powder and light vanilla.  Flavor carries on the chocolate theme nicely and the ABV is hard to find.  This is a stellar chocolate beer and unique and tasty combination of two great KC artisans!

12oz. bottle enjoyed in my new CC snifter, with another big thanks to GodOfThunder.  Pours a hazy amber color with a moderate white head.  Aroma is fresh cut wood, fresh citrus, some perfume floral notes, and some fresh fruit juice.  Flavor is more citrus, fresh wood, floral and ripe fresh orange or tangerine fruits.  Another creative and nicely done CC beer, thanks again J!
beer_name: Cigar City White Oak Jai Alai India Pale Ale

review_blob: 12oz. bottle, with a big thanks to GodOfThunder for one from a sweet load of CC goodness!  Pours pitch black with a moderate creamy tan head.  Aroma is quite nice, with a hops leading the way, pine/resin, some sharp citrus, grass, cedar, molasses, and a little honey.  Flavor is dominated by a great balance of pine, cedar, a little chocolate, honey and molasses.    Man, I love what these guys do with cedar; when it works, it really works!  Thanks again to GOT, much appreciated J!

12oz. bottle, 2010 vintage, with a huge thanks to WeisGuy for the hookup!  Pours a dark cola color with some ruby highlights and a thin and whispy covering that settles to a moderate ring.  Aroma is just lovely, with loads of candied dark fruits, rich toffee and caramel, some vanilla and oak, more overripe mashed dark fruits, just a whiff of bourbon and some thick molasses.  Wow, right up my alley!  Flavor follows along stunningly, with more big notes of toffee, caramel, candied and ripe dark fruits, vanilla, oak, and some bourbon.  Only a hint of prickliness on the palate with some warmth.  The big ABV is there but very much in the background.  Stellar all the way around and certainly did not disappoint, I could sip on this all night.  Thanks again Shane!
beer_name: Kuhnhenn Fourth Dementia (4D) Old Ale - Bourbon Barrel

review_blob: 750ml bottle, Batch 002, with a big thanks to beastiefan2k.  Pours a golden straw color.  Aroma is inviting with fresh citrus, lighter bretty funk, some lemon zest and light floral.  Flavor is somewhat light and lively, with more citrus, brett, floral and lemon zest.  Definitely more gentle and nuanced than I was expecting from this one.  Very drinkable and tasty, thanks again for sharing Eugene!

750ml bottle, 2005 vintage, shared by beastiefan2k, thanks Eugene!  Pours darker caramel with some burgundy highlights.  Aroma is loaded with rich malts, toffee, caramel, ripe dark fruits, and some subdued barrel notes of oak and vanilla that are nicely complimentary.  Flavor is more full flavored malts, caramel, toffee, ripe dark fruits and some light oak and vanilla to add to the sweetness, but mostly the barrel is fading away.  This one is big and rich, and impressed with how its holding up, thanks again Eugene!

500ml bottle.  Pours a ruby tinted black with a large and dense dark tan head that hangs around a long time and leaves great lacing.  Aroma is smoke, peat, earth, and molasses, mingling nicely with a strong wild honey note.  The honey makes a very interesting and enjoyable compliment to the barrel and works really well together.  Flavor is stronger on the earth, smoke and peat, with good amounts of molasses and honey still present.  I found this one to be a surprise on how much I enjoyed it, especially how the honey and smoky peat worked together.  If it was $5-$7 less per bottle and Id grab a few more.

22oz. bomber, #3,760, with thanks to dgugliuzza from over on BA, and selfishly shared with no one on my own little New Years Eve Eve party by myself.  Pours a nice dark black with a minimal brown head that quickly disappears leaving a still surface.  Aroma is lovely, with lots of barrel notes, oak, vanilla, molasses, bourbon, chocolate, and ripe dark fruits.  There is a definite initial note of alcohol that dissipates as it has a chance to breathe, and other than needing a little time found this quickly went away.  Flavor is equally up to the task, with more rich vanilla, oak, molasses, chocolate and a blend of ripe dark fruits.  The carbonation is just a touch higher than Id hope, with some prickliness, but retains a smooth and coating finish.  A fine beer, but not quite at the level of something like FiftyFiftys PVW Eclipse.  Embarrassed at how much this costs, but for a one bottle, one time kind of thing there are no regrets.  Thanks again Danny!
beer_name: Goose Island Bourbon County Stout - Rare

review_blob: 12oz. can, originally sampled thanks to Dansting, and another as a bonus from alexsdad06, thanks guys.  Pours a cola-ish caramel brown with a moderate fizzy tan head.  Aroma is spice, toffee, caramel, and some general toasted malts.  Flavor is a bit watery, with more general spice, toasted malts, toffee and caramel.  Drinkable, just not too exciting.

22oz. bomber, with a big thanks to alexsdad06.  Pours dark brown with a moderate dark tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, espresso, ripe dark fruits, some toasty oak, and a hint of vanilla and bourbon, but very much in the background.  Flavor follows nicely with more chocolate, rich ripe fruits, some espresso, and hints of bourbon, toasted oak and vanilla.  The barrel is very nice on this one, and both the barrel aging and higher ABV are barely noticeable and in a complimentary role.  Wow, this one did not disappoint, thanks a ton Brad!
beer_name: Jackie Os Bourbon Barrel Dark Apparition

review_blob: 22oz. bottle, with thanks to alexsdad06.  Pours a syrupy looking jet black with a minimal dark tan head that reduces to a whispy covering.  Aroma starts a little more muted than expected but does open up some as it warms, with some dark roasty malts, bittersweet chocolate, overripe dark fruits, and some sweet espresso.  Flavor is nicely sweet without going overboard, with more bittersweet chocolate mingled with juicy and ripe dark fruits, some roasty oats, and espresso.  Smooth and full on the palate, and the ABV is very well hidden.  Nicely done, thanks again Brad!

12oz. bottle, batch #9934, with thanks to beastiefan2k.  Pours a clear light golden straw color with a large white cap.  Aroma is lemon, lemon zest, citrus, light hay, wheat and some biscuit.  Flavor is mildly tart, with more lemon and zest, biscuit, harvest wheat, and some white grape skin.  Very light and sessionable, and interesting enough for what theyre after with this one.  Thanks Eugene!

22oz. bomber, with thanks to StFun for the great Wants List bonus!  Pours a dark cola brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is toasted malts, a little smoke, some chocolate, and earthy hops.  Flavor is more toasted/roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, light caramel and hints of smoke and earthiness.  Very enjoyable and tasty.  Glad to finally get the chance to try this one, thanks again Josh!

37.5cl bottle, with a huge thanks to Doodler for such a rare bottle!  Pours dark black with a larger dark brown head that lingers.  Aroma is quite nice, especially as it sits and warms a bit, with lush ripe and dried dark fruits, chocolate, a little rich espresso, some oak, and fresh cherry.  Flavor is also lovely, with more fresh cherry, dried dark fruits, chocolate, molasses, espresso and light oak.  Interesting to see the port barrel qualities on this one.  Nice stuff, thanks again Scott!

6.3oz. handbottle with another huge thanks to StFun!  Pours blacks with a slight center forming head of loose and large bubbles and settles to a thin ring.  Aroma is not quite and complex or intense as the OADL, but very rich and lovely with vanilla bean, chocolate, oak, caramel and some dried dark fruits.  Flavor is definitely on the sweeter side, with more rich vanilla, bittersweet chocolate, dried dark fruits, caramel and oak.  Toes the line nicely between sweet and a sticky mess.  Minimal carbonation with a nice smooth and almost syrupy mouthfeel.  Another nice dessert beer sipper, and great stuff but would take the OADL over this any day.  Thanks again Josh. much appreciated!
beer_name: Three Floyds Dark Lord Russian Imperial Stout (Bourbon Vanilla Bean)

review_blob: 6.3oz. handbottle, with a giant thank you to StFun!  Wow, Ive pretty much given up on ever getting to DLD so ruled out any chance of trying this one, but Josh came through with a HUGE hookup on this and the VBDL!  Pours black and mostly still with just a few loose bubbles that quickly recede.  The aroma just jumps out of the glass, with some of the richest and most intense notes of vanilla, caramel, oak, and chocolate I have ever encountered in a beer.  Really this smells more like an awesome dessert than beer.  Theres a little bourbon floating around in the nose too, but well placed amongst the other and more intense qualities.  I could linger on the aroma all day and not get tired of this one.  Flavor is equally impressive, with more intense chocolate, caramel, vanilla, oak, and a hint of bourbon.  Palate is thick, slick and oily with no real carbonation.  Truly a slow sipping dessert beer, and very, very impressive, thanks again Josh!
beer_name: Three Floyds Dark Lord Russian Imperial Stout (Bourbon Barrel Aged)

review_blob: 750ml bottle, shared by Beastiefan2k, thanks Eugene!  Pours a murky caramel brown with a minimal tan head.  Aroma is pretty muted on this one, with just the slightest funk, a little oak and tart cherrry, and thats about it, at least until someone mentioned dill pickles :-).  Flavor is also fairly bland on the outset, with a little funk, oak, and some mild cherry sourness, and finishing with slight chocolate.  Not bad by the long stretch, just seemed to try to do too much and not really pulling any of it off.  Thanks again for sharing Eugene!

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: 750ml, with another thanks to craytonic.  Hands down the most uniquely odd beer I can remember.  Pours a cloudy yellow golden with a large sea foam head that lingers.  Aroma is very strongly tea like, with big herbal and earthy notes, along with some fruits, lemon zest, funk and tart acid but mostly pushed to the background.  This thing moved around a ton on the nose, and at times really loved the aroma and others almost found it offensive.  Flavor was also herbal and earthy, with a nice blend of fresh fruits, lemon zest and a little funky acid.  Undeniably unique and tasty, but the nose just kept throwing me off.  Thanks again Matt!

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: 750ml bottle, another from craytonic from a BA trade.  Quite different from the acid bomb that is V006, and more along the lines of what I was hoping for.  Pours a hazy brighter yellow golden with a nice white head head that lingers.  Aroma is a nice blend of fresh fruits - apricot, melon, mango, orange, peach, grape skins and berries, along with some lighter oak, funk and tart acidic notes.  Flavor focuses more on the fresh fruits, grapes, apricot, peach and berries, with a nice balance of funk and acid.  Im sure this seemed much more balanced and nicely subtle coming off the V006, but found this to be my favorite of the trio.  Thanks again Matt!

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: 750ml bottle from a trade with craytonic over on BA.  Fortunately no massive gusher on this one, and pours a murky reddish brown with a good sized off-white pinkish head.  The initial nose is only a hint of how acidic this thing is.  Nice notes of sour cherry, fresh orange, raspberry, and some mango and island fruits along with some light funk.  Regardless, the overwhelming acid is front and center, and only continues to the taste.  Almost an unbearable acidic hit regardless of how small a sip, with more tart cherry, fresh raspberry and other fruits, lesser barrel notes, and some funk.  Definitely not for the faint of heart, and unfortunately lacking any subtlety or nuance I was hoping for.  Thanks Matt!

Fresh bottling, and a nice bonus from pepsican on a Johns order, thanks dude!  Pours a slightly hazy copper/orange color with a moderate off-white head.  Aroma is bursting with grapefruit, orange peel, citrus, and a slight bit of caramel and pine.  Flavor is sharply bitter, with more grapefruit rind, citrus, and lesser notes of caramel, pine, grass and floral.  Quite drinkable and tasty, thanks again Andy!

180ml bottle, #2011, with a big thanks to Doodler!  Pours dark brown/black with a minimal slow forming, quickly disappearing tan head.  Aroma starts with those signature De Molen roasty malts, followed quickly by char, oak, chocolate, espresso, just a hint of barrel/whiskey, and some light caramel, vanilla and ripe dark fruits.  Flavor brings more of the barrel into place, but very soft and gentle, blending nicely with more rich chocolate, espresso roast, some char/smoke, caramel, vanilla, and dark fruits.  Palate is extremely smooth and gentle, yet coating and full.  Wow, a very refined BA Imperial Stout, thanks much Scott!
beer_name: De Molen Hel & Verdoemenis Misto BA

review_blob: 11.2oz., #48129 bottled Jan 2009.  Pours a typical dark brown/black ith a moderate tan head that quickly dissipates to a whispy covering.  Aroma is peat, smoke, light whiskey, some chocolate, coffee and oak.  Understandable more muted until it warms a bit.  Flavor is more nuanced, with more peat, smoke, chocolate, whiskey, and oak, with the oak/wood and subtle smoke/peat notes working really well together.  Both a thinner palate and less boozy than expected.  Nice stuff.

2006 nip bottle, #74/100, generously shared by Beastiefan2k!  Pours a caramel amber with a thin and spotty tan head.  Aroma is very malty, with caramel, light toffee, a little honey sweetness, and surprisingly minimal but notable alcohol.  As expected the alcohol is there on the flavor, but smooth and tame enough to keep things on track.  More big malts, toffee and caramel.  Interesting stuff and sure glad for the chance to try, thanks again Eugene.

22oz., bottled on 11/05/10.  Pours a typical dark brown/black, but with a minimal thin and spotty head of dark tan that quickly reduces to a completely flat surface.  After the lackluster pour, the aroma definitely gets things going, with great barrel notes of rich vanilla, bourbon, oak, and chocolate.  Agree with comments from other raters that the nose on this one isnt as different from the regular as the Coffee, but theres a definitely uptick with the decadent vanilla which is nice.  Flavor brings it home in great order, with more vanilla, oak, chocolate, and bourbon.  Theres a great slick and oily mouthfeel with just a little prickly carbonation to keep things interesting thats also well received.  Overall this is another nice one to go along with the Coffee release, and makes me more hopeful to get a chance to try the Rare.
beer_name: Goose Island Bourbon County Stout - Vanilla Bourbon Barrel

review_blob: 500ml bottle from Binnys Downtown in Chicago.  Pours dark brown/black with a sizable and lasting darker tan head.  Aroma is a nice combination of meat and campfire smoke, light peat, espresso, a little chocolate and some general heavily roasted malts.  Flavor is more smoke, peat, espresso and light chocolate.  Not over the top complex, but delivers well as a great smoked.  Wish this was available locally as Id grab another bottle or two for the winter.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Had a couple bottles of this through Sinners Club.  Pours a nice dark brown/black with a thicker tan head that lingers with good lace.  Aroma is lots of barrel, with the usual suspects including vanilla, oak, molasses, rich milk chocolate, bourbon, and some over ripe dark fruits.  Flavor is also barrel heavy, with more vanilla, lighter bourbon notes, chocolate, dark fruits, and espresso notes.  A little heavier mouthfeel also helps make this as a nice cold weather sipper.  Lots of barrel, but no real surprise there, and it ends up as a nice blend of two great beers.

Okay, gotta break my rating hiatus for this one.  After trying a few of the Shorts wacky beers (Smores, Key Lime, etc.), this one does it for me.  While the Key Lime was tasty, and the Smores wasnt anything special, this has excellent use of the blood orange that really work well with some great citrus hops notes.  Very fresh and fruity all the way through, with the blood orange and related citrus notes giving the most push from the nose through the flavor.  Very unique, very tasty.  12oz. bottle, purchased in Kalamazoo several weeks ago.

750ml bottle from South Bay.  Pours a beautiful clear sparkling burgundy with ruby highlights and a large fluffy tan head that lingers.  Aroma is a nice blend of malty goodness, with caramel, toffee, a variety of ripe and candied dark fruits, brown sugar, and some molasses and hints of chocolate.  Flavor is more of the same, with a great blend of malty goodness.  As always, AleSmith delivers excellence.

750ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with a large and fluffy tan head that sticks around forever and leaves some great lacing.  Looks beautiful in the glass all the way around.  Aroma is roasty malts, espresso, chocolate, a little earthy hops, and lesser notes of molasses and ripe dark fruits.  Flavor is more roasted malts, chocolate, ground coffee, and more earthy hops.  Nothing that beats you over the head, but very nicely put together and quite an enjoyable beer to get through the evening with.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada 30th Anniversary Fritz & Kens Ale

review_blob: 22oz. bottle.  Pours dark brown/black with a large fluffy tan head.  Aroma is milk chocolate, light and rich espresso, molasses, some ripe dark fruits, vanilla, oak, and light bourbon; wow lots going on, but gels well together.  Flavor is more chocolate, molasses, espresso, nice notes of bourbon, oak and vanilla, and a little more overripe dark fruits.  Very well put together from start to finish.

12.7oz. corked and caged handbottle, with a huge thanks to Doodler for the unsolicited hook-up on this long time want!  Pours motor oil thick and black with a minimal head of dark brown loose bubbles that leaves only a thin ring.  Aroma is oak, vanilla, chocolate, light espresso, whiskey, caramel, and molasses.  Flavor brings everything together nicely, with more oak, whiskey, caramel, roasty malts, chocolate and vanilla.  Silky smooth, and the barrel aging is a great compliment to the regular Ten FIDY, thanks again Scott, I definitely owe you one!
beer_name: Oskar Blues Ten FIDY - Stranahans Colorado Whiskey Barrel

review_blob: 12oz. can, GUARANTEED to be awesome by Beastiefan2k.  Pours a clear amber with a large frothy off-white head and leaves a good amount of lace.  Aroma is pine/resin, earth, and light floral, caramel and island fruits.  Flavor is nicely hopped, with more pine, light floral and some balancing caramel.  A little watery on the finish, but overall not too bad.

22oz. bomber, 2009 bottled Aug 14, with a big thanks to FlssmrBrewAlum.  Gushes on opening, with a ton of light pinkish white foam that settles down in a few minutes.  Pours a cloudy rose color with a large fluffy pink-white head that lingers.  Aroma is oak, grape skins, ripe fruits, and some dusty funk.  Flavor is very mild, with more grape skins, oak, ripe dark fruits and only a hint of funk.  Nothing too crazy here, but more subtle and light.  A nice summer drinker with enough complexity to keep it interesting.  Thanks again Adam!

16oz. can with thanks to theisti.  Pours a slightly cloudy orange amber with a large frothy tan head.  Aroma is earthy, grass and citrus hops, along with a little bread and biscuit.  Flavor is initially some pine, grass and earthy hops, some more bread and biscuit malts, and a slight lingers citrus on the finish.  Nicely done, clean, crisp and quite enjoyable on a hot summer night.  Thanks Tim!

Tap @ Barleys OP.  Pours a dirty lighter brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is a nice blend of chocolate, funk, hay, a little grass, oak, and some minimal notes of dark fruits, coffee and nuts.  Really nice on the nose, and much more than I was expecting.  Flavor continues the trend, with an interesting blend of light chocolate malts and funk, earthy notes of hay, grass, and oak, and more dark fruits, coffee and caramel.  Impressive stuff.
beer_name: Odell Saboteur Brett Barrel Brown Ale

review_blob: 750ml bottle, Lot A.  Pours dark brown with burgundy highlights and a moderate tan head.  Aroma is nicely bretty, with some musty cobwebs, funk, dark fruits, a fair amount of earthiness, and some oak notes.  Flavor is more of the same, with more of the light funk/brett stuff, oak, dark fruits, cherry and earthy qualities.  The spice is pushed more to the background to me from the regular Pannepot.  Quite nice!

12oz. bottle, with another thanks to Beastiefan2k.  Pours a hazy amber, with a minimal off-white head.  Aroma is candied dark fruits, caramel, and agree with earlier comments of maple.  Flavor is more candied and dried dark fruits, maple, caramel, toffee, and some general dried dark fruits.  Not overly interesting, but enough going on to keep my attention, thanks for sharing Eugene!
beer_name: Kuhnhenn Mayhem Belgian Dark Strong Ale

review_blob: 22oz. bomber, with thanks to wavers1.  Pours dark brown with a frothy tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, a good dose of molasses, oak, and a lesser amount of bourbon.  Flavor is more oak, molasses, chocolate, and roasty malts.  Very tasty stuff, thanks again Baker!

750ml bottle, with a big thanks to Beastiefan2k for sharing.  Pours dark brown/black with a minimal tan head, no lacing.  Aroma has oats, a real European roasty malt thing going on, chocolate, a little coffee, some dark fruit, but mostly that lovely roasty malt thing.  Flavor is more of the same, with more roasty malts, chocolate, coffee, and a little vanilla.  This one is gentle yet diverse, and just excellent.  Thank you, thank you Eugene for sharing this long time Want list beer, it did not disappoint!

22oz. gold wax bomber.  Pours a clear orange golden with a fluffy off-white head.  Aroma is grapefruit, caramel, pine, grass and citrus.  Flavor has a nice bitter bite, with more grapefruit, pine, citrus, and some caramel and bread.  Another easy drinking IPA from Flossmoor, but not as exciting as others from them.
